user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital on February 10, 2024, presenting with symptoms of cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon evaluation, you were diagnosed with lobar pneumonia, unspecified organism (ICD-10 code J18.1).

During your admission, a chest X-ray was performed, which revealed consolidation in the left lower lobe, confirming the presence of pneumonia. Your initial laboratory results showed elevated markers of inflammation, with a C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 60 mg/L and a white blood cell (WBC) count of 12 x10^9/L. Hemoglobin and platelet levels remained within normal range. These findings guided the initiation of empirical antibiotic therapy with intravenous amoxicillin at a dose of 500 mg every 8 hours.

Over the course of your hospital stay, you responded positively to the treatment. Your vital signs improved daily, with a reduction in fever and stabilization of oxygen saturation levels. By February 11, 2024, your CRP had decreased to 50 mg/L, and WBC count was 11 x10^9/L. As clinical conditions progressed favorably, the dosage and delivery of amoxicillin were adjusted, and you were transitioned to oral antibiotics by February 13, 2024.

Throughout your stay, your lab results and vital signs demonstrated a trend towards normalization. By February 13, your CRP and WBC counts had decreased further to 20 mg/L and 7 x10^9/L, respectively, and your temperature normalized to 36.5°C. Oxygen saturation was consistently stable at this time.

On February 14, 2024, after completing a comprehensive review, you were deemed medically fit for discharge. Your condition showed significant improvement, and your inflammatory markers continued to decline under the prescribed treatment regimen.

At the time of discharge, you were instructed to continue with oral amoxicillin 250 mg daily for the next five days. Continuation of Atorvastatin 20 mg nightly was also advised as per your routine management. A follow-up appointment has been arranged in the outpatient clinic in two weeks to reassess your recovery and ensure continued improvement.

Should you experience any recurrence of symptoms such as fever, increased shortness of breath, or chest discomfort, you are advised to seek medical attention promptly.

We wish you a smooth and swift recovery. Please attend your follow-up appointment as scheduled for optimal management of your health.

Sincerely,

Dr. Smith
